subject: Design
courseTitle: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us

topics.title: The Tacoma Narrows Bridge: Beauty That Killed

hook.text: In 1940, a bridge twisted itself apart in a 40 mph wind. The collapse was caught on film â€” and changed engineering.

buildup.text: The Tacoma Narrows Bridge was designed to be elegant and slender â€” thin road deck, graceful suspension cables.

discovery.text: Wind caused the deck to oscillate violently â€” a phenomenon called aeroelastic flutter that engineers hadn't modeled.

twist.text: Cheaper, wider bridge designs wouldn't have failed. Beauty and cost-cutting combined to create catastrophe.

climax.text: After Tacoma Narrows, every suspension bridge in the world was redesigned. One failure improved thousands.

punchline.text: The most famous bridge collapse taught us that looking good isn't enough.

quiz.question: What caused the Tacoma Narrows Bridge to collapse?
options: Aeroelastic flutter â€” wind-induced oscillation in the thin deck

topics.title: The Challenger Disaster: When Engineers Are Ignored

hook.text: On January 28, 1986, the Space Shuttle Challenger exploded 73 seconds after launch. Seven crew members died.

buildup.text: Engineers at Morton Thiokol warned that cold weather would cause O-ring seals in the rocket boosters to fail.

discovery.text: The O-rings were designed for warmer temperatures. At 36Â°F, they lost elasticity and couldn't seal the joint.

twist.text: Managers overruled the engineers' objections to launch. Schedule pressure beat technical judgment.

climax.text: Challenger proved that design failures are often management failures â€” ignoring known risks.

punchline.text: The O-ring worked perfectly in every test. Except the one that mattered.

quiz.question: What was the root cause of the Challenger disaster?
options: O-ring seals failed in cold weather â€” and management ignored engineer warnings

topics.title: The Titanic: Unsinkable by Design, Sunk by Arrogance

hook.text: The Titanic had 20 lifeboats for 2,200 passengers. Designers thought the ship itself was the lifeboat.

buildup.text: The hull had 16 watertight compartments. It could float with four flooded. The iceberg breached five.

discovery.text: The watertight compartments didn't reach the ceiling. Water poured over the top from one to the next.

twist.text: More lifeboats were possible but removed because they 'cluttered the deck.' Aesthetics trumped safety.

climax.text: The Titanic's design flaw wasn't engineering â€” it was overconfidence. No backup plan for the unthinkable.

punchline.text: Confidence sank a ship. Hubris is the deadliest design flaw.

quiz.question: Why were there insufficient lifeboats on the Titanic?
options: Designers removed them to keep the deck uncluttered and believed the ship was unsinkable

topics.title: The Hyatt Regency Walkway: A Simple Drawing Error

hook.text: In 1981, two suspended walkways in a Kansas City hotel collapsed during a dance party. 114 people died.

buildup.text: The original design hung both walkways from a single set of long rods running from ceiling to floor.

discovery.text: During construction, a contractor changed to shorter rods. This doubled the load on the upper walkway's connections.

twist.text: The change seemed minor â€” a fabrication convenience. No engineer re-checked the load calculations.

climax.text: The Hyatt collapse proved that small design changes can have catastrophic consequences if not re-analyzed.

punchline.text: A small sketch change killed 114 people. Details are life and death.

quiz.question: What caused the Hyatt Regency walkway collapse?
options: A construction change doubled the load on connections without engineering review

topics.title: The Chernobyl Control Room: Designed to Confuse

hook.text: Chernobyl's control room had thousands of identical switches and no clear hierarchy. Operators couldn't read the danger.

buildup.text: The RBMK reactor's control panel used confusing abbreviations, buried critical warnings, and lacked visual hierarchy.

discovery.text: Operators disabled safety systems during a test â€” partly because the interface made it unclear what they were doing.

twist.text: Under stress, operators couldn't tell which switch controlled which reactor system.

climax.text: Chernobyl was a design failure at every level â€” reactor physics, control interface, and safety culture.

punchline.text: A confusing dashboard helped cause the worst nuclear disaster ever.

quiz.question: How did the control room design contribute to Chernobyl?
options: Confusing interface made it hard to understand system status and risks

topics.title: Healthcare.gov: The $1.7 Billion Website Crash

hook.text: In 2013, the US launched Healthcare.gov. On day one, only six people enrolled. Six. Out of millions.

buildup.text: Healthcare.gov was built by 55 contractors with no central technical leadership. Nobody tested the full system.

discovery.text: The site couldn't handle traffic, had 500+ bugs at launch, and required users to create accounts before browsing plans.

twist.text: A team of Silicon Valley engineers fixed the site in weeks. The technology was simple â€” the management was the problem.

climax.text: Healthcare.gov proved that digital design failures are almost always organizational failures, not technical ones.

punchline.text: Good intentions plus bad design equals $1.7 billion in waste.

quiz.question: What was the main cause of Healthcare.gov's failure?
options: No central technical leadership and no end-to-end testing

topics.title: The 2000 Florida Ballot: An Election Lost by Design

hook.text: In 2000, a confusing ballot in Palm Beach County may have changed who became US president.

buildup.text: Palm Beach County used a 'butterfly ballot' â€” candidates on both sides with punch holes in the middle.

discovery.text: The layout confused thousands of voters. Pat Buchanan received 3,407 votes â€” far above his expected 600.

twist.text: The ballot designer, Theresa LePore, was a Democrat trying to make the text bigger for elderly voters.

climax.text: A well-intentioned design decision may have determined who became President of the United States.

punchline.text: Bad design doesn't just frustrate users. Sometimes it changes history.

quiz.question: What was wrong with the 2000 Florida butterfly ballot?
options: The layout confused voters, causing thousands to vote for the wrong candidate

topics.title: Windows Vista: Death by a Thousand Features

hook.text: Microsoft spent $6 billion on Windows Vista. Users hated it so much they demanded the old version back.

buildup.text: Vista added security prompts for every action, required powerful hardware, and broke compatibility with older software.

discovery.text: The User Account Control pop-ups were so annoying that users disabled security entirely â€” defeating the purpose.

twist.text: Apple's 'I'm a Mac' ads mocked Vista mercilessly. Mac sales surged directly because of Vista's failures.

climax.text: Vista proved that adding features without considering user experience creates products people actively avoid.

punchline.text: The best security feature is useless if it annoys users into turning it off.

quiz.question: Why did users disable Vista's User Account Control?
options: The constant permission pop-ups were so annoying users preferred no security

topics.title: Google Glass: Too Creepy to Succeed

hook.text: Google Glass was revolutionary technology that nobody wanted to be seen wearing. Social design killed it.

buildup.text: Launched in 2013, Glass let you record video, get directions, and check messages â€” all hands-free.

discovery.text: People near Glass wearers felt surveilled. Bars banned 'Glassholes.' The technology worked; the social design failed.

twist.text: Glass pivoted to enterprise use â€” warehouses, surgery, manufacturing â€” where recording is expected, not creepy.

climax.text: Google Glass proved that product design must account for social context, not just individual utility.

punchline.text: The most advanced wearable failed because other people hated it.

quiz.question: Why did Google Glass fail as a consumer product?
options: The technology worked but people around wearers felt surveilled

topics.title: The Mars Climate Orbiter: Metric vs. Imperial

hook.text: In 1999, NASA lost a $125 million spacecraft because one team used metric and another used imperial. Oops.

buildup.text: The Mars Climate Orbiter was designed to study Mars's atmosphere. Lockheed Martin built its software.

discovery.text: Lockheed's code outputted force in pound-seconds. NASA's code expected newton-seconds. Nobody caught the mismatch.

twist.text: The orbiter entered Mars's atmosphere at the wrong angle and burned up. A unit conversion error destroyed years of work.

climax.text: The disaster showed that interface design between systems matters as much as the systems themselves.

punchline.text: $125 million lost because nobody checked the units. Design details matter.

quiz.question: What caused the loss of the Mars Climate Orbiter?
options: One team used metric while another used imperial units

topics.title: Samsung Galaxy Note 7: The Exploding Phone

hook.text: In 2016, Samsung phones started catching fire in pockets, cars, and even on airplanes. 2.5 million were recalled.

buildup.text: Samsung crammed a larger battery into a thinner case. The design left almost no space for battery expansion.

discovery.text: When batteries heat up, they swell. With no room to expand, the electrodes short-circuited and caught fire.

twist.text: Samsung's replacement batteries had a different flaw â€” a welding defect. The recall had to be recalled.

climax.text: The Note 7 cost Samsung $5.3 billion and showed that rushing design timelines has explosive consequences.

punchline.text: The thinnest phone became the most dangerous. Millimeters matter.

quiz.question: What design flaw caused the Galaxy Note 7 fires?
options: The battery had no room to expand in the thin case, causing short circuits

topics.title: The Ford Pinto: The Cost of a Human Life

hook.text: Ford knew the Pinto's fuel tank could explode in rear collisions. They calculated fixing it wasn't worth it.

buildup.text: The Pinto's fuel tank sat between the rear axle and bumper â€” vulnerable to even low-speed rear impacts.

discovery.text: Ford's internal memo valued a human life at $200,000 and concluded the $11-per-car fix wasn't cost-effective.

twist.text: When the memo leaked, public outrage forced a recall of 1.5 million vehicles. Ethics, not engineering, was the failure.

climax.text: The Pinto case established that cost-benefit analysis cannot override human safety in product design.

punchline.text: When you calculate the price of a life, you've already failed at design.

quiz.question: Why didn't Ford initially fix the Pinto's fuel tank?
options: They didn't know about the problem
They calculated lawsuits would cost less than the $11-per-car fix

topics.title: Thalidomide: The Drug That Changed Product Testing

hook.text: In the late 1950s, a sleeping pill for pregnant women caused 10,000 babies to be born with severe limb deformities.

buildup.text: Thalidomide was marketed as perfectly safe. It hadn't been tested on pregnant animals before release.

discovery.text: The drug crossed the placental barrier and disrupted limb development in the first trimester.

twist.text: The drug had been tested â€” but not on pregnant women. No one checked the most vulnerable users.

climax.text: Thalidomide led to the modern drug approval process â€” rigorous testing, clinical trials, and safety reviews.

punchline.text: Thalidomide proved: test on everyone who'll use it, or don't ship.

quiz.question: What lasting change did the thalidomide disaster create?
options: Rigorous drug approval processes with mandatory clinical trials

topics.title: Boeing 737 MAX: When Software Overrides Pilots

hook.text: Boeing added software to the 737 MAX that could push the nose down. Pilots weren't told it existed.

buildup.text: Boeing added MCAS software to compensate for larger engines that changed the plane's flight characteristics.

discovery.text: MCAS relied on a single sensor. When it failed, the software repeatedly forced the nose down against pilot commands.

twist.text: Boeing didn't tell airlines about MCAS to avoid requiring expensive pilot retraining. Cost savings killed people.

climax.text: The MAX showed that hiding design complexity from users â€” even trained pilots â€” can be fatal.

punchline.text: Software designed to help pilots fly ended up preventing pilots from flying.

quiz.question: Why was the Boeing 737 MAX's MCAS system dangerous?
options: It relied on one sensor and overrode pilots who didn't know it existed

topics.title: The Juicero: Over-Engineering a Juice Squeeze

hook.text: A $700 WiFi-connected juicer that squeezed proprietary bags â€” you could squeeze them by hand just as well.

buildup.text: The device used 4 tons of force to squeeze proprietary fruit packs. It had custom chips, a motor, and a QR scanner.

discovery.text: Bloomberg reporters squeezed the packs by hand and got juice just as fast. The machine was unnecessary.

twist.text: The company shut down within five months of the Bloomberg article. $120 million in venture capital, gone.

climax.text: Juicero became a symbol of Silicon Valley excess â€” over-engineering problems that don't need solving.

punchline.text: The most expensive lesson in design: solve real problems, not imaginary ones.

quiz.question: Why did Juicero fail?
options: Hand-squeezing the packs worked just as well, making the $400 machine unnecessary

topics.title: The Walkie-Talkie Building: The Skyscraper That Melted Cars

hook.text: In 2013, a London skyscraper's curved glass facade focused sunlight like a magnifying glass and melted parked cars.

buildup.text: 20 Fenchurch Street's concave south face reflected and concentrated sunlight into a 'death ray' on the street below.

discovery.text: Temperatures at the focal point reached 243Â°F â€” enough to melt plastic, scorch paint, and fry an egg on the sidewalk.

twist.text: The architect, Rafael ViÃ±oly, had the same problem with a previous building in Las Vegas. The lesson wasn't learned.

climax.text: A permanent sunshade was installed. The 'Walkie Scorchie' proved that ignoring physics has consequences.

punchline.text: A skyscraper accidentally weaponized sunlight. Twice. By the same architect.

quiz.question: How did the Walkie-Talkie building melt cars?
options: Its concave glass facade focused sunlight into a concentrated beam

topics.title: Pruitt-Igoe: The Housing Project That Destroyed Itself

hook.text: In 1972, the US government dynamited its own $36 million housing project. The design had failed in every way.

buildup.text: Pruitt-Igoe in St. Louis was 33 tower blocks for 10,000 people â€” modernist design applied to social housing.

discovery.text: Cost cuts eliminated playgrounds, landscaping, and ground-floor shops. The buildings became isolated and inhospitable.

twist.text: The same architect, Minoru Yamasaki, later designed the World Trade Center. Scale didn't equal success.

climax.text: Pruitt-Igoe proved that housing design must serve communities, not just provide shelter.

punchline.text: The death of modernist housing was televised â€” 33 buildings blown up on live TV.

quiz.question: Why did the Pruitt-Igoe housing project fail?
options: Cost cuts eliminated community spaces, creating isolated, inhospitable buildings

topics.title: The Millennium Bridge: The Wobbly Opening Day

hook.text: London's Millennium Bridge opened in 2000. It swayed so violently that pedestrians grabbed the railings in terror.

buildup.text: Foster + Partners designed a sleek, flat suspension bridge across the Thames â€” beautiful and minimal.

discovery.text: When crowds walked across, their footsteps synchronized with the bridge's natural sway, amplifying it dangerously.

twist.text: The phenomenon â€” synchronous lateral excitation â€” was known in engineering but nobody applied it to pedestrian bridges.

climax.text: Dampers were added, the bridge reopened, and engineers worldwide updated their pedestrian bridge calculations.

punchline.text: A bridge designed for beauty forgot the most basic user: walking humans.

quiz.question: What caused London's Millennium Bridge to wobble?
options: Pedestrians' synchronized footsteps amplified the bridge's natural sway

topics.title: Brutalist Housing: When Concrete Dreams Became Nightmares

hook.text: In the 1960s, architects loved raw concrete housing towers. The residents who lived in them didn't.

buildup.text: Brutalist housing promised 'streets in the sky' â€” elevated walkways connecting tower blocks into communities.

discovery.text: In reality, walkways became windswept, stairwells became crime spots, and concrete aged into gray misery.

twist.text: Today, brutalist buildings are Instagram-famous. Architecture tourists photograph what residents endured.

climax.text: Brutalism shows that architects' visions and residents' lived experiences can be tragically different.

punchline.text: Buildings designed for the people were hated by the people.

quiz.question: Why did brutalist housing projects often fail?
options: Elevated walkways and concrete environments became hostile to residents

topics.title: The Vdara Death Ray: Vegas Does It Again

hook.text: A curved glass hotel in Las Vegas focused sunlight into a beam that melted pool furniture and burned guests.

buildup.text: The Vdara Hotel's south-facing concave surface acted as a solar concentrator, creating a roaming hot spot.

discovery.text: Guests reported singed hair, melted bags, and what they called the 'Vdara death ray' on the pool deck.

twist.text: The architect was Rafael ViÃ±oly â€” the same designer who later caused the London 'Walkie Scorchie' incident.

climax.text: When the same architect makes the same mistake twice, the flaw isn't in the building â€” it's in the process.

punchline.text: Some architects design death rays. This one did it as a hobby.

quiz.question: What connects the Vdara Hotel and London's Walkie-Talkie building?
options: Same architect made the same solar concentration mistake in both

topics.title: The Pepsi Logo Redesign: A $1 Million Disaster

hook.text: Pepsi paid $1 million for a logo redesign backed by a 27-page document referencing the golden ratio and gravity.

buildup.text: The Arnell Group produced a 27-page strategy document referencing Da Vinci, Pythagoras, and gravitational pull.

discovery.text: The actual logo change? The white stripe in the Pepsi circle got slightly wider. That's it.

twist.text: When the document leaked, the design world laughed. Pseudo-intellectual justification masked a minimal change.

climax.text: The Pepsi fiasco shows that design rationale must be honest, not inflated with pseudoscience.

punchline.text: $1 million to make a stripe wider â€” with a 27-page document explaining why.

quiz.question: What made the Pepsi logo redesign infamous?
options: A $1M fee with a pseudo-scientific 27-page rationale for a minimal change

topics.title: Gap's Logo Disaster: When Crowds Kill Creativity

hook.text: In 2010, Gap revealed a new logo. The internet revolted so fiercely that Gap reversed the change in six days.

buildup.text: The classic blue box with serif 'GAP' was replaced by a Helvetica wordmark with a tiny blue gradient square.

discovery.text: Thousands of parodies appeared online. 'Make your own Gap logo' generators went viral. It became a global joke.

twist.text: Gap's crowd-sourcing attempt â€” asking the internet to submit better logos â€” made things even worse.

climax.text: The Gap fiasco proved that brand equity lives in the audience, not the company. You can't redesign love.

punchline.text: The shortest-lived logo in corporate history lasted exactly six days.

quiz.question: Why did Gap reverse its logo change after only six days?
options: Massive public backlash and online mockery

topics.title: The 2012 Olympics Logo: Design That Divided a Nation

hook.text: London's 2012 Olympics logo cost Â£400,000 and was so controversial that 50,000 people signed a petition against it.

buildup.text: Wolff Olins designed jagged, angular numerals spelling '2012' in hot pink. The public was horrified.

discovery.text: 48,000 people signed a petition demanding a redesign. Iran threatened to boycott, seeing hidden text in the shapes.

twist.text: By the time the Games started, the logo had grown on people. The events overshadowed the controversy.

climax.text: The 2012 logo proves that bold design provokes initial hate but can succeed if the experience delivers.

punchline.text: The most hated logo became the face of one of the most loved Olympics.

quiz.question: How did public opinion on the 2012 Olympics logo change over time?
options: Initially hated, it was accepted once the successful Games started

topics.title: IHOP to IHOb: A Prank That Backfired

hook.text: In 2018, IHOP changed its name to IHOb to promote burgers. Customers and competitors mocked them mercilessly.

buildup.text: The rebrand was meant to promote their new burger menu. The entire campaign centered on the letter flip.

discovery.text: Competitors mocked it mercilessly. Wendy's tweeted: 'Not really afraid of the brand that changed its name to IHOb.'

twist.text: IHOP admitted it was just a promotion and reverted in weeks. But the damage to brand perception lingered.

climax.text: The stunt showed that rebranding for attention without substance confuses customers and invites ridicule.

punchline.text: Sometimes the cleverest marketing idea is the dumbest design decision.

quiz.question: What went wrong with IHOP's rebrand to IHOb?
options: The stunt was mocked by competitors and confused brand identity

topics.title: Norman Doors: Designing Things People Can't Use

hook.text: You've pushed a door that says 'pull.' It's not your fault â€” it's a design failure named after Don Norman.

buildup.text: Don Norman's 1988 book 'The Design of Everyday Things' argued that bad design makes smart people feel stupid.

discovery.text: A 'Norman Door' has a handle that suggests pulling when you should push. The door's design lies to your hands.

twist.text: Norman Doors are everywhere â€” confusing faucets, ambiguous light switches, mystery stovetop controls.

climax.text: Norman's insight: if users fail, blame the design, not the user. This principle transformed product development.

punchline.text: You're not bad at opening doors. Doors are bad at being designed.

quiz.question: What is a 'Norman Door'?
options: A door made by Norman company
A door whose design misleads users about how to open it

topics.title: Swiss Cheese Model: How Disasters Actually Happen

hook.text: No single failure causes a disaster. Accidents happen when multiple small holes align â€” like Swiss cheese slices.

buildup.text: Imagine layers of defense as slices of Swiss cheese. Each has holes â€” weaknesses that alone aren't dangerous.

discovery.text: A disaster happens when the holes in every layer line up, letting a hazard pass through all defenses.

twist.text: The model shows that fixing one layer isn't enough. Resilient design needs multiple independent safeguards.

climax.text: Swiss Cheese thinking transformed aviation, medicine, and nuclear safety â€” anywhere failure means death.

punchline.text: The best safety model in the world is named after a cheese.

quiz.question: What does the Swiss Cheese Model explain?
options: How multiple small failures align to cause a disaster

topics.title: Fail-Safe vs. Safe-to-Fail: Two Philosophies

hook.text: A fail-safe design prevents failure. A safe-to-fail design assumes failure is inevitable and limits the damage.

buildup.text: Fail-safe engineering tries to eliminate every possible failure mode. But complex systems always find new ways to break.

discovery.text: Wetlands absorb floods. Flexible buildings sway in earthquakes. They're designed to fail gracefully.

twist.text: The internet was designed safe-to-fail â€” packets reroute around damage. That's why it survived every crisis.

climax.text: The best-designed systems don't prevent all failure. They make failure survivable.

punchline.text: Perfect is impossible. Survivable is the real design goal.

quiz.question: What is the difference between fail-safe and safe-to-fail design?
options: Fail-safe prevents failure; safe-to-fail assumes failure and limits damage

topics.title: Post-Mortem Culture: Learning From Failure at Google

hook.text: When Google's services fail, they write a 'blameless post-mortem' â€” a public document explaining what went wrong.

buildup.text: Post-mortems analyze failures without blaming individuals. The goal is to fix systems, not punish people.

discovery.text: Google publishes these reports internally. Some are shared publicly. Failure becomes institutional knowledge.

twist.text: Companies that punish failure get employees who hide mistakes. Blameless cultures catch problems faster.

climax.text: The post-mortem turned design failure from shameful to educational. Every crash makes the system smarter.

punchline.text: The best companies aren't failure-free. They're failure-literate.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of a 'blameless post-mortem'?
options: To analyze failures without blaming individuals, improving systems

topics.title: The Precautionary Principle: Design for What You Don't Know

hook.text: If a new material might cause cancer in 20 years, should we use it now? The precautionary principle says no.

buildup.text: The principle says: if a product might cause serious harm, act preventively even without complete scientific certainty.

discovery.text: Europe applies it to chemicals, GMOs, and AI. Products must be proven safe before release, not after damage.

twist.text: Critics say it blocks innovation. Supporters say asbestos, lead paint, and CFCs prove we should have been more cautious.

climax.text: The precautionary principle asks designers to imagine the worst case â€” and design against it before launch.

punchline.text: The best design disasters are the ones that never happen.

quiz.question: What does the precautionary principle require of product designers?
options: Act preventively against potential harm even without complete proof

topics.title: Gap's Logo Disaster: Six Days of Internet Fury

hook.text: In 2010, Gap replaced its iconic blue box logo. The internet exploded with rage within hours.

buildup.text: The new logo used Helvetica with a tiny gradient square. Customers called it generic and soulless.

discovery.text: After six days of relentless mockery and parody logos flooding social media, Gap reverted to the original.

twist.text: Gap never revealed the redesign cost, but industry estimates put it at $100 million including rollout plans.

climax.text: The Gap logo disaster proved that brand identity belongs to customers, not boardrooms.

punchline.text: Six days proved that customers own your brand. Not you.

quiz.question: How long did Gap's controversial new logo last?
